author: Adam Kurkjian
title: Bill Belichick: 'There was nothing magic about halftime' | The Blitz | with Jeff Howe & Karen Guregian
text:
Bill Belichick spoke highly of his team's "total team effort" in a 30-6 win over the Cowboys today, and said the offense's increased production in the second half was a matter of constant adjustment rather than anything done at halftime.
With the win, the Patriots improve to 4-0 heading into next Sunday's trip to Indianapolis to face the Colts in a rematch of last season's AFC title game.
"There was nothing magic about halftime," Belichick said of the team bouncing back from the five sacks Tom Brady suffered in the opening 30 minutes. "We had to identify it and handle it from our first series. Defensively, they gave us a look they hadn't really shown us.
The Patriots kept Tom Brady upright in the second half and it paid off with 17 points and two touchdown passes.
Belichick was not surprised by how well defensive end Greg Hardy and linebacker Rolando McClain disrupted the pocket.
"(Hardy's) a good player," Belichick said. "I've said that all week. McClain, too."
Brady completed 20-of-27 passes for 275 yards and two touchdowns but was battered throughout.
Asked if Brady's performance answered any questions about his toughness, Belichick said, "I don't think anyone's ever questioned Tom's toughness. Who's done that?"
Belichick noted how linebacker Jamie Collins "seemed to be all over the field."
As for Dion Lewis, the breakout star of the offense this season, the running back's production, including his tackle-breaking 10-yard touchdown catch, is no longer a surprise, either.
"Dion's been giving us a lot of productive plays," he said. "He's been doing it for us all year."
